facts.text: Plaintiff auction-purchased the entire revenue paying estate, Touzi No. 6 of the 24 Parganas, on January 6, 1936.
Plaintiff obtained possession from the Collector in May-June, 1936.
Plaintiff annulled and avoided all intermediary interests except those protected under s. 37 of Act XI of 1859, by notices in or about June, 1936.

Suit instituted by plaintiff on December 6, 1945, for ejectment of defendants from disputed property described as Mal land of Touzi No. 6 and other Touzies, seeking khas possession to the extent of his 1/6th share jointly with defendants.

Defendants contested that suit lands were not Mal lands, never assessed to revenue, not included in Mal assets of Touzi No. 6, and were Brahmottar Lakheraj lands never within the regularly assessed estate Touzi No. 6.

Trial court (Subordinate Judge) by judgment dated April 20, 1948, held land was Mal land of Touzi No. 6, defendants' interest not protected under s. 37, decreed suit for possession with mesne profits.
First defendant appealed to Calcutta High Court in July 1948.
Bengal Land Revenue Sales (West Bengal Amendment) Act VII of 1950 came into force on March 15, 1950, while appeal pending.
Plaintiff applied for delivery of possession on March 28, 1949.

Judgment debtor filed petition on March 29, 1949, praying for one month's time to bring stay order from High Court and stay of process; disposed by order: 'Judgment-debtor files a petition praying for one months time to bring a stay order and for stay of process in the meantime. Heard learned lawyer. Re-call and put up in the presence of both parties Inform Nazir.'
High Court on March 8, 1954, called for finding on whether possession delivered before Amending Act.
Subordinate Judge found possession delivered to decree-holder on March 29, 1949.
High Court held delivery of possession without authority and a nullity.
High Court found land part of permanent tenure held rent-free (Niskar), protected under ss. 4 & 7; decree void under s.7(2), s.7(1)(a) applies for abatement and refund of court fees.
High Court by judgment dated June 16, 1958, allowed appeal, set aside trial court decree, directed abatement of suit and refund of court fees; parties to bear own costs.
Supreme Court appeal on certificate granted by High Court.
Defendants' property was a tenure in existence from before 1910; failed to prove existence since Permanent Settlement.

legal_issues.text: The main question for determination... is the scope and effect of ss. 4 & 7 of the Bengal Land Revenue Sales (West Bengal Amendment) Act VII of 1950.
Is the land in dispute Mal land of Touzi No. 6 or is it Lakheraj?
Whether the suit/appeal abates under s.7(1)(a) or decree void under s.7(2); effect of delivery of possession.

petitioner_arguments.text: Suit when instituted was a good one in view of provisions of s.37 of Act XI of 1859; s.4 of Amending Act would not govern as (1) delivery of possession already given in execution before Amending Act, controversy closed; (2) s.4 not retrospective.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.37 Act XI of 1859; s.4 & s.7 Amending Act

respondent_arguments.text: Suit lands not Mal lands, Brahmottar Lakheraj; delivery of possession contested.
Land part of permanent tenure held rent-free (Niskar), protected; delivery a nullity.

court_reasoning.text: s.4 prima facie prospective, but s.7 retrospective for pending litigations; suit pending on appeal at commencement, continuation of suit.

Suit for ejectment in pursuance of s.37; would not have been validly instituted had Amending Act in force due to amended s.37 protecting tenures existing at notification of sale (cl.b(i)); defendants' tenure existed before 1910.
Suit falls under s.7(1)(a): pending suit/appeal abates if not valid under new Act; not under s.7(1)(b) or s.7(2) as decree not final.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Suit abated on March 15, 1950 under s.7(1)(a); no need to consider possession delivery.

court_reasoning.text: Amending Act grants relief to tenure-holders whose estates sold before 1950 if not wiped out; covers pending suits/appeals/decrees subject to provisos.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature did not intend to reopen closed transactions where possession delivered before commencement.

holdings.text: Suit pending in High Court on appeal abated on March 15, 1950 under s.7(1)(a) of Amending Act.
Delivery of possession during pendency of appeal need not be considered due to abatement.

precedents_cited.case_name: Decided cases of different High Courts
precedents_cited.relevance: Effect of order on stay petition during execution.

statutes_cited.name: Bengal Land Revenue Sales Act, 1859 (Central Act XI of 1859)
statutes_cited.relevance: Original provisions for annulment; amended by s.4.

statutes_cited.name: Bengal Land Revenue Sales (West Bengal Amendment) Act, 1950 (West Bengal Act VII of 1950)
statutes_cited.relevance: Amends s.37 to protect certain tenures; s.7 gives retrospective effect causing abatement of pending suits/appeals and voiding decrees.

statutes_cited.name: Bengal Tenancy Act, 1885
statutes_cited.relevance: For purposes of s.37 as amended.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; suit held to have abated under s.7(1)(a) of Amending Act on March 15, 1950; High Court order modified in reasoning but result affirmed.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellant; abatement of suit and refund of court fees implied.
outcome.costs: Not specified in Supreme Court judgment.

key_quotes.text: "The main question for determination in this appeal... is the scope and effect of ss. 4 & 7 of the Bengal Land Revenue Sales (West Bengal Amendment) Act West Bengal Act VII of 1950."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "It is well-settled that a pending appeal is a continuation of the suit out of which it arises."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key to applying s.7(1)(a) to pending appeal.

key_quotes.text: "Hence, in partial disagreement with the High Court, we hold that the suit pending in the High Court on appeal had abated on March 15, 1950, under s.7(1)(a)"
key_quotes.speaker: court
